Endocrine System.What is the endocrine system?: A collection of ductless glands that secrete hormones into the bloodstream to regulate metabolism, growth, reproduction, and other body functions.
Endocrine System.What is the role of the hypothalamus?: Acts as the master regulator by producing releasing and inhibiting hormones that control the anterior pituitary gland.
Endocrine System.What hormones are produced by the anteri: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone), ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone), GH (Growth Hormone), LH (Luteinizing Hormone), FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone), Prolactin.
Endocrine System.What is the function of TSH (Thyroid-Sti: Stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), which regulate metabolism.
Endocrine System.What is the function of ACTH (Adrenocort: Stimulates the adrenal cortex to release cortisol and other glucocorticoids.
Endocrine System.What is the function of GH (Growth Hormo: Promotes growth, cell reproduction, and regeneration in tissues, especially bones and muscles.
Endocrine System.What is the function of LH (Luteinizing: LH triggers ovulation and stimulates the production of sex hormones in the ovaries and testes; FSH stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles and sperm production.
Endocrine System.What is the role of prolactin?: Stimulates milk production in the mammary glands.
Endocrine System.What hormones are stored and released by: ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone) and Oxytocin, both produced by the hypothalamus.
Endocrine System.What is the function of ADH (Antidiureti: Promotes water retention by the kidneys, reducing urine volume and helping to maintain blood pressure.
Endocrine System.What is the function of oxytocin?: Triggers uterine contractions during childbirth and milk ejection during breastfeeding.
Endocrine System.What is the function of T3 and T4?: Regulate metabolism, heart rate, and body temperature; T3 is the more active form.
Endocrine System.What is the function of calcitonin?: Lowers blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclast activity and promoting calcium deposition in bones.
Endocrine System.What is the function of PTH (Parathyroid: Raises blood calcium levels by stimulating osteoclasts, increasing calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and enhancing calcium absorption in the intestines.
Endocrine System.What hormones are produced by the adrena: Glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol), Mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone), and Androgens.
Endocrine System.What is the function of cortisol?: Regulates metabolism, reduces inflammation, and helps the body respond to stress.
Endocrine System.What is the function of aldosterone?: Regulates sodium and potassium balance by promoting sodium retention and potassium excretion in the kidneys.
Endocrine System.What is the function of epinephrine and: Prepare the body for fight-or-flight responses by increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and blood glucose levels.
Endocrine System.What is the function of insulin?: Lowers blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake into cells and glycogen storage.
Endocrine System.What is the function of glucagon?: Raises blood glucose levels by promoting glycogen breakdown and glucose release by the liver.
Endocrine System.What is the function of melatonin?: Regulates sleep-wake cycles and circadian rhythms, with production increasing in response to darkness.
Endocrine System.What is the function of estrogen?: Regulates the menstrual cycle, promotes the development of secondary sexual characteristics, and prepares the uterus for pregnancy.
Endocrine System.What is the function of progesterone?: Prepares the uterus for implantation of a fertilized egg and maintains pregnancy.
Endocrine System.What is the function of testosterone?: Regulates sperm production and the development of male secondary sexual characteristics.

Cardiovascular System.What are the main functions of the cardi: To transport oxygen, nutrients, hormones, and waste products throughout the body, and to help regulate body temperature and pH balance.
Cardiovascular System.What are the four chambers of the heart?: Right atrium, right ventricle, left atrium, left ventricle.
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the right atrium: Receives deoxygenated blood from the body via the superior and inferior vena cava.
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the right ventri: Pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs through the pulmonary arteries.
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the left atrium?: Receives oxygenated blood from the lungs via the pulmonary veins.
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the left ventric: Pumps oxygenated blood to the body through the aorta.
Cardiovascular System.What are the atrioventricular (AV) valve: The Tricuspid Valve (right side) and the Mitral/Bicuspid Valve (left side) between the atria and ventricles.
Cardiovascular System.What are the semilunar valves?: The Pulmonary Valve (between right ventricle and pulmonary artery) and the Aortic Valve (between left ventricle and aorta).
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the sinoatrial (: Acts as the pacemaker of the heart, initiating electrical impulses that cause the heart to beat.
Cardiovascular System.What is the pathway of blood through the: Right atrium → right ventricle → pulmonary artery → lungs → pulmonary veins → left atrium → left ventricle → aorta.
Cardiovascular System.What is the cardiac cycle?: The sequence of events that occur when the heart beats, including diastole (relaxation) and systole (contraction).
Cardiovascular System.What is the role of the ECG (electrocard: Measures the electrical activity of the heart, showing the P wave, QRS complex, and T wave.
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the arteries?: Carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the tissues of the body (except the pulmonary arteries).
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of the veins?: Carry deoxygenated blood back to the heart (except the pulmonary veins).
Cardiovascular System.What is the function of capillaries?: Serve as the site of gas, nutrient, and waste exchange between the blood and tissues.
Cardiovascular System.What is blood pressure?: The force exerted by circulating blood on the walls of blood vessels, typically measured in systolic/diastolic values.
Cardiovascular System.What regulates blood pressure?: The autonomic nervous system (baroreceptors), hormones (RAAS, ADH, ANP), and the kidneys.
Cardiovascular System.What is the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosteron: A hormone system that regulates blood pressure and fluid balance, involving renin, angiotensin, and aldosterone.
Cardiovascular System.What is hypertension?: Chronically high blood pressure, which increases the risk of heart disease, stroke, and other complications.
Cardiovascular System.What is atherosclerosis?: The buildup of plaque in the arteries, leading to reduced blood flow and an increased risk of heart attack.
Cardiovascular System.What is a myocardial infarction?: Commonly known as a heart attack, it occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, causing tissue damage.
Cardiovascular System.What are arrhythmias?: Abnormal heart rhythms that can disrupt normal cardiac function, ranging from benign to life-threatening.

Lymphatic and Immune System.What are the main functions of the lymph: To return excess interstitial fluid to the bloodstream, absorb dietary fats, and provide immune responses.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is lymph?: A clear fluid similar to plasma that contains immune cells, proteins, and waste products.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What are the primary lymphoid organs?: Thymus and bone marrow, where lymphocytes (T cells and B cells) mature.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the role of lymph nodes?: Filter lymph, trapping pathogens and foreign particles, and house lymphocytes that initiate immune responses.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the spleen?: The largest lymphoid organ, which filters blood, recycles old red blood cells, and helps fight infection.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the function of the thymus?: Site of T cell maturation, crucial for the adaptive immune response.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What are B cells?: Lymphocytes that produce antibodies, which neutralize or mark pathogens for destruction.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What are T cells?: Lymphocytes that directly attack infected cells or regulate other immune responses.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the difference between innate an: Innate immunity is the body's first line of defense against pathogens (non-specific), while adaptive immunity targets specific invaders and has memory.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is inflammation?: A localized immune response to injury or infection, characterized by redness, heat, swelling, and pain.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the function of antibodies?: Proteins produced by B cells that bind to specific antigens on pathogens, marking them for destruction.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the complement system?: A group of proteins that enhance the immune response by promoting inflammation, opsonization, and lysis of pathogens.
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is an autoimmune disease?: A condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus).
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is the difference between active an: Active immunity involves the body's own production of antibodies (e.g., after infection or vaccination), while passive immunity is provided by antibodies from another source (e.g., mother to baby, antibody injections).
Lymphatic and Immune System.What is lymphedema?: Swelling due to blockage or damage to lymphatic vessels, preventing normal lymph drainage.

Respiratory System.What are the primary functions of the re: To exchange gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide) between the air and the blood, and to help regulate blood pH.
Respiratory System.What is the pathway of air through the r: Nose/mouth → pharynx → larynx → trachea → bronchi → bronchioles → alveoli.
Respiratory System.What is the function of the nasal cavity: Filters, warms, and moistens air as it enters the respiratory system.
Respiratory System.What is the role of the larynx?: Contains the vocal cords and routes air and food into the proper channels.
Respiratory System.What is the function of the trachea?: The windpipe that conducts air from the larynx to the bronchi, reinforced by C-shaped cartilage rings.
Respiratory System.What are the bronchi and bronchioles?: The bronchi are large airways that branch from the trachea into each lung, and bronchioles are smaller branches that lead to the alveoli.
Respiratory System.What are the alveoli?: Tiny air sacs in the lungs where gas exchange occurs between the air and the blood.
Respiratory System.What is the process of gas exchange in t: Oxygen diffuses from the alveoli into the pulmonary capillaries, while carbon dioxide diffuses from the blood into the alveoli to be exhaled.
Respiratory System.What muscles are involved in inspiration: The diaphragm and external intercostal muscles contract, expanding the thoracic cavity and drawing air into the lungs.
Respiratory System.What is the role of the diaphragm in bre: A dome-shaped muscle that contracts to increase the volume of the thoracic cavity during inspiration.
Respiratory System.How is oxygen transported in the blood?: Primarily bound to hemoglobin in red blood cells as oxyhemoglobin.
Respiratory System.How is carbon dioxide transported in the: Dissolved in plasma, bound to hemoglobin as carbaminohemoglobin, or converted to bicarbonate ions in the plasma.
Respiratory System.What is the role of the medulla oblongat: It controls the basic rhythm of breathing by sending signals to the respiratory muscles.
Respiratory System.What are chemoreceptors and how do they: Sensory receptors that detect changes in blood pH, CO2, and O2 levels, and adjust ventilation to maintain homeostasis.
Respiratory System.What is asthma?: A chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and coughing.
Respiratory System.What is Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Di: A group of lung diseases, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis, that cause airflow obstruction and breathing difficulties.
Respiratory System.What is pneumonia?: An infection of the lungs that inflames the air sacs, leading to fluid accumulation and impaired gas exchange.
Respiratory System.What is a pulmonary embolism?: A blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, usually caused by a blood clot, leading to decreased oxygenation of blood.

Digestive System.What is the main function of the digesti: To break down food into nutrients that can be absorbed into the bloodstream and eliminate waste.
Digestive System.What are the primary processes of digest: Ingestion, mechanical digestion, chemical digestion, absorption, and defecation.
Digestive System.What is the role of the mouth in digesti: Begins mechanical digestion through chewing (mastication) and chemical digestion with saliva containing amylase.
Digestive System.What is the function of the salivary gla: Produce saliva, which contains enzymes (amylase) that begin the breakdown of carbohydrates.
Digestive System.What is the esophagus?: A muscular tube that transports food from the pharynx to the stomach via peristalsis.
Digestive System.What is peristalsis?: Involuntary, wave-like muscle contractions that move food through the digestive tract.
Digestive System.What is the role of the stomach in diges: Secretes gastric juices, including HCl and pepsin, to chemically break down proteins and churns food to mix it with digestive enzymes.
Digestive System.What is chyme?: The semi-liquid mixture of partially digested food and gastric juices that forms in the stomach and moves into the small intestine.
Digestive System.What is the small intestine and its func: The primary site of nutrient absorption; consists of three sections: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.
Digestive System.What is the role of the duodenum?: The first part of the small intestine where most chemical digestion occurs, receiving bile from the liver and pancreatic enzymes.
Digestive System.What is the function of the villi and mi: Increase the surface area for absorption of nutrients into the bloodstream.
Digestive System.What is the role of the liver in digesti: Produces bile, which emulsifies fats to aid in their digestion.
Digestive System.What is the function of the gallbladder?: Stores and concentrates bile, releasing it into the duodenum when needed for fat digestion.
Digestive System.What are the exocrine functions of the p: Produces digestive enzymes (amylase, lipase, proteases) and bicarbonate to neutralize stomach acid in the duodenum.
Digestive System.What is the role of the large intestine?: Absorbs water and electrolytes, forming solid feces, and houses gut bacteria that produce vitamins like vitamin K.
Digestive System.What is the function of the rectum and a: Store and expel feces during defecation.
Digestive System.What is the role of bile in fat digestio: Bile emulsifies fats, breaking them into smaller droplets that are more easily digested by enzymes like lipase.
Digestive System.What is the role of the enteric nervous: The 'gut brain,' a local neural network that regulates gastrointestinal motility and secretion independently of the central nervous system.
Digestive System.What hormones regulate digestive process: Gastrin (stimulates gastric juice secretion), secretin (stimulates bicarbonate release), and cholecystokinin (CCK, stimulates bile and pancreatic enzyme release).
Digestive System.What is GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Di: A condition where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn and potential damage to the esophageal lining.
Digestive System.What is a peptic ulcer?: An erosion of the stomach or duodenal lining caused by excess acid or infection with Helicobacter pylori.
Digestive System.What is Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)?: A functional disorder characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and altered bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation).
Digestive System.What is Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, including conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Urinary System.What are the primary functions of the ur: To remove waste products from the blood, regulate blood volume and pressure, balance electrolytes and pH, and detoxify the body.
Urinary System.What is the structure and function of th: Bean-shaped organs that filter blood, remove waste, and regulate electrolyte balance; contain nephrons, the functional units.
Urinary System.What is the nephron and its role?: The functional unit of the kidney that filters blood, reabsorbs needed substances, and secretes waste into the urine.
Urinary System.What is the glomerulus?: A network of capillaries in the nephron where blood filtration occurs.
Urinary System.What is the role of the proximal convolu: Reabsorbs nutrients, ions, and water from the filtrate back into the bloodstream.
Urinary System.What is the loop of Henle and its functi: Creates a concentration gradient in the medulla to concentrate urine by reabsorbing water and salts.
Urinary System.What is the role of the distal convolute: Further reabsorbs ions and water, regulated by hormones like aldosterone.
Urinary System.What is the function of the collecting d: Final adjustments to urine composition; reabsorbs water under the influence of ADH.
Urinary System.What is glomerular filtration?: The process by which blood pressure forces water, ions, and small molecules from the blood into Bowman's capsule, forming the filtrate.
Urinary System.What is tubular reabsorption?: The process by which the nephron reclaims valuable substances from the filtrate back into the bloodstream.
Urinary System.What is tubular secretion?: The active transport of waste products and excess ions from the blood into the filtrate, primarily in the DCT and collecting duct.
Urinary System.What is the role of ADH in the kidneys?: Increases water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, reducing urine volume and increasing blood volume.
Urinary System.What triggers the release of renin?: Low blood pressure or low sodium levels in the blood stimulate renin release from the kidneys.
Urinary System.What is the function of aldosterone?: Promotes sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, leading to water retention and increased blood pressure.
Urinary System.What is the role of the ureters?: Transport urine from the kidneys to the bladder via peristalsis.
Urinary System.What is the function of the bladder?: Stores urine until it is excreted.
Urinary System.What is the function of the urethra?: Carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body during urination.
Urinary System.What is micturition?: The process of urination, involving the coordinated relaxation of the urethral sphincters and contraction of the bladder muscles.
Urinary System.What is acid-base balance and how is it: The maintenance of the body's pH within a narrow range; regulated by buffer systems, respiratory compensation, and renal compensation.
Urinary System.What is chronic kidney disease (CKD)?: Progressive loss of kidney function over time, potentially leading to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requiring dialysis or transplantation.
Urinary System.What is acute kidney injury (AKI)?: Sudden loss of kidney function, often reversible with prompt treatment.
Urinary System.What are kidney stones (renal calculi)?: Crystallized minerals in the kidney that can obstruct urine flow, causing pain and potential damage to the kidney.
Urinary System.What is urinalysis?: A test that examines the content of urine to detect and diagnose various conditions, including infections, kidney disease, and diabetes.

Reproductive System.What are the primary functions of the re: To produce, store, and transport gametes (sperm and eggs) and facilitate fertilization and the development of offspring.
Reproductive System.What is the structure and function of th: Male reproductive organs that produce sperm (spermatogenesis) and secrete testosterone.
Reproductive System.What is spermatogenesis?: The production of sperm through meiosis in the seminiferous tubules of the testes.
Reproductive System.What are the components of sperm?: Head (contains DNA), midpiece (packed with mitochondria for energy), and tail (flagellum for movement).
Reproductive System.What is the role of the epididymis?: Coiled tube where sperm mature and are stored until ejaculation.
Reproductive System.What is the function of the vas deferens: Transports sperm from the epididymis to the urethra during ejaculation.
Reproductive System.What is the role of the seminal vesicles: Produce seminal fluid that contains fructose, providing energy for sperm.
Reproductive System.What is the function of the prostate gla: Produces a slightly alkaline fluid that makes up part of the semen and neutralizes acidity in the female reproductive tract.
Reproductive System.What is the function of the bulbourethra: Secrete mucus that lubricates the urethra during ejaculation.
Reproductive System.What is the structure and function of th: Female reproductive organs that produce eggs (oogenesis) and secrete estrogen and progesterone.
Reproductive System.What is oogenesis?: The production of eggs through meiosis, beginning before birth and resuming during puberty.
Reproductive System.What occurs during ovulation?: The release of a mature egg (secondary oocyte) from the ovary, typically around day 14 of the menstrual cycle.
Reproductive System.What is the role of the fallopian tubes: Transport the egg from the ovary to the uterus and serve as the site of fertilization.
Reproductive System.What is the structure and function of th: A muscular organ that provides a site for implantation of the fertilized egg and supports fetal development.
Reproductive System.What is the function of the endometrium?: The inner lining of the uterus that thickens in preparation for pregnancy and is shed during menstruation if fertilization does not occur.
Reproductive System.What is the role of the cervix?: The narrow lower portion of the uterus that opens into the vagina and dilates during childbirth.
Reproductive System.What is the menstrual cycle?: The monthly cycle of changes in the female reproductive system, including the development and release of an egg and preparation of the uterus for pregnancy.
Reproductive System.What are the phases of the menstrual cyc: Follicular phase, ovulation, luteal phase, and menstruation.
Reproductive System.What is the function of estrogen in the: Promotes the growth of the endometrium and regulates the menstrual cycle.
Reproductive System.What is the role of progesterone?: Maintains the endometrium for potential pregnancy and inhibits uterine contractions.
Reproductive System.What is fertilization?: The union of a sperm cell and an egg cell, typically occurring in the fallopian tube.
Reproductive System.What is the role of the placenta during: An organ that provides oxygen and nutrients to the developing fetus and removes waste products.
Reproductive System.What are the trimesters of pregnancy?: First trimester (organogenesis), second trimester (growth and development), third trimester (final maturation and preparation for birth).
Reproductive System.What is Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts, leading to irregular menstrual cycles and infertility.
Reproductive System.What is endometriosis?: A condition where endometrial tissue grows outside the uterus, causing pain and potential fertility issues.
Reproductive System.What is erectile dysfunction (ED)?: The inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse.
Reproductive System.What is infertility?: The inability to conceive after one year of unprotected intercourse, which can be due to various factors affecting either the male or female reproductive systems.
